bibl.title: Fred S. Walton v. John G. Boyle.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

org.orgName: The United States Circuit Court, Northern Division, State of Washington

div1.ab: In the Circuit Court of the United States, Ninth Judicial Circuit, District of Washington, Northern Division.
In the matter of F. S. Walton, on habeas corpus.
div1.p: John G. Boyle makes return to the writ of Habeas Corpus served upon him by A. L. Dilley, Deputy United States Marshal for the District of Washington, upon the 7th day of September, 1901, in the above entitled matter, which writ is hereto attached, and respectfull shows:
1. That he is the regularly elected, qualified and acting city Marshal of the City of North Yakima.
2. That the City of North Yakima now is and was at all times hereinafter mentioned, duly incorporated under the laws of the State of Washington as a City of the third class.

3. That on the 4th day of April, 1898, the City Council of of said City of North Yakima, passed an ordinance No. 265, entitled an ordinance in relation to licenses, which ordinance was on the 5th day of April, 1898, duly approved by O.A. Fechter, Mayor of said City and which ordinance was thereafter duly published and in pursuance of law and recorded in the ordinance books of said City, a copy of which is hereto attached, marked exhibit "A"and made a part of this return. That on the 3 day of September, 1900, the City Council of said City of North Yakima, passed an ordinance No. 298, entitled an ordinance to amend sections 1 and 10 of said ordinance No. 265, entitled an ordinance relating to licenses aprroved April 5th, 1898, which ordinance relating to licenses approved April 5th, 1898, which ordinance was duly approved on the 4th day of September, 1900, by George S. Hough, Mayor Pro tem, and which ordinance was thereafter published and recorded in the ordinance book of said City of North Yakima, a copy of which is hereto attached, marked exhibit "B" and made a part of this return.
4. That said ordinances now are and ever since the date of their
passage, approval and publication, have been in full force and effect

5. That on the 5th day of September, 1901, the above named relator, F. S. Walton, in violation of said ordinances and without first having procured a license therefor, so to do, did unlawfully hawk certain goods, wares and merchandise, to-wit:

Quaker herbs in the City of North Yakima, by offering said quaker herbs for sale in said City and by selling the same at public out-cry in a public place therein as more fully appears from the complaint for the violation of said ordinances, a copy of which is to this return attached.

6. That thereupon a complaint, for the violation of said ordinances duly verified by Vestal Snyder, City Attorney of said City, was duly filed on the 5th day of September, 1901, with W. I. Lince who at the time was the duly appointed, or qualified and acting police justice of said City of North Yakima, a copy of which complaint with the endorsements thereon, is hereto attached, marked exhibit "C" and made a part of this return.

7. That thereupon, on the said 5th day of September, 1901, the said police justice duly issued a warrant for the apprehension and arrest of said relator, which warrant was duly placed in thehands of this respondent and thereupon on the said 5th day of September, 1901, pursuant to the commands therein contained, this respondent duly arrested and took into custody said relator and took him before said police justice and thereupon, upon the application of said relator, a change of venue was granted from said police justice to J. A. Taggard, Justice of the Peace of North Yakima Precinct, in Yakima County, State of Washington, being the nearest Justice of the Peace.

8. That afterwards, on the 6th day of September, 1901, said cause came on regularly for trial before said J. A. Taggard, Justice of the Peace, as aforesaid, and after the hearing thereof said relator being present in person and by his counsel, a judgment was rendered in said Court and cause, whereby it was considered that said relator pay a fine of Five Dollars, together with the costs of said action, a copy of which judgment is hereto attached, marked exhibit "D"
and made a part of this return.

9. that said relator having failed and refused to pay said fine and costs, a commitment was issued by said J. A. Taggard, Justice of the Peace, as aforesaid, and placed in the hands of this respondent and thereupon by virtue of the commands therein contained, did take said relator into custody on the 6th day of September, 1901, and placed him in the City jail of the City of North Yakima, a copy of which commitment is hereto attached, marked exhibit "E" and made a part of this return.

10. That said relator so remained in jail until the 7th day of September, 1901, at the hour of ten o'clock A.M., this respondent discharged said relator from custody and never since said time has the said John G. Boyle had the custody or control of said relator nor has he imprisoned him nor restrained him of his liberty nor has he had the said relator in his possession, custody or power since said date and he now has no power, custody or control over him.

11. Said respondent further shows that said writ of habeas corpus was served upon him on the 7th day of September, 1901, at the hour of four o'clock P.M. That respondent had no notice, power prior to said date and did not at said date, nor at any other time prior to the time the same was served upon him, have any notice or knowledge that said writ or any writ of habeas corpus has been issued.

12. That this respondent does not hold said relator by virtue of said commitment or by process of any Court whatever but pursuant to the commands in said writ of habeas corpus named, the respondent with the full consent and at the express request of said relator and with the full knowledge on the part of the said relator, of all the facts herein stated, and in order to obey said writ of habeas corpus in so far as it was in the power of this respondent so to do, has brought said relator into this Court by virtue of said writ of habeas corpus and not otherwise and has brought said relator into Court at his express request and with his full consent and with his full knowledge, that he was not detained under commitment aforesaid nor under process of any other Court of this and this respondent now

avers that since he released and discharged said relator from custody on the said 7th day of September, 1901, that he has restr not restrained him of his liberty and that he has not had him under his power, possession or control.

13-- Respondent further avers that said relator is engaged in the sale of what are generally known as patent medicines; that relator represents himself as a Quaker Doctor, and that he hawks and vends said medicines by travelling from town to town and offering the same at public outcry upon the streets and public places of various towns visited by him; that said relator carries with him a travelling troup of players, and gives open air concerts for the purpose of attracting corwds of people, in order to be able to more readily sell his wares; that he is engaged in the sale of what is known as "Quaker Herbs", "Pile Remedies" and shaving soap; that the method of conducting the business of said relator attracts large crowds of people on the streets, thoroughfares and public places where said business is carried on; that by reason thereof the said City of North Yakima is put to large additional expense in policing said city and preserving the public peace and good order therein.

14-- Said relator, as this respondent is informed and believes and therefore alleges, sells large quantities of the medicines and nostrums aforesaid at an enormous profit, and this respondent averts that said relator can well afford from the profits made and the quantitites of medicine sold to pay the license in said ordinance mentioned.

15-- That said relator ships said medicines and nostrums into the State of Washington in original packages, and thereafter and when the same are offered for sale, he breaks said packages and offers the same for sale at retail in single packages and not in the packages so shipped in.
16-- Respondent further making return to said writ, denies that said relator is unlawfully imprisoned, detained and fined or restrained of his liberty by respondent at North

Yakima or elsewhere; denies that he has any knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief as to whether said relator is a resident and citizen of the City of Portland in the State of Oregon; denies that he has any knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief as to whether the trade mark "Quaker Medicine" has been filed by the relator and as to whether he ahs taken out a trade mark under the laws of the United States; denies that he has any knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief as to what said medicine is composed of, and as to whether it is not composed of the products of the soil or vegetables of Yakima County; denies that he has any knowledge or information sufficient to form a belief as to whether the component parts of said medicine and quaker herbs and nostrums are grown in various States of the United States other than the State of Washington; denies that said relator was detained by respondent under said committment at the time of the granting of said writ; denies that the sum of Four Hundred Dollars ($400.00) is a prohibitive and unreasonable license, and that Twenty- five Dollars ($25.00) per day is a prohibitive and unreasonable license; denies that the net profits from the sale of said medicine would not equal said license; and denies that the effect of said license is to prohibit petitioner from doing business in the City of North Yakima; and denies that it infringes his right under the Constitution of the United States to engage in business in North Yakima upon equal terms with the persons selling the products of Yakima County, and that it interferes with the right of commerce as guaranteed by the Constitution of the United States between the citizens of different states; denies that said ordinance is in violation of the Constitution and laws of the

United States; denies that said ordinance discriminates against the residents and products of all other portions of the United States in favor of the products of Yakima County; denies that said ordinance is in violation of the right of commerce; denies that it is a violation of the Constitution of the United States which gives to the citizens of each State of the Union like privileges, rights and immunities in every other State of said Union had by the citizens of said State.

14. That respondent respectfully protests against the jursidiction of this Court and respectfully avers that the matters and things aforesaid do not show a violation of the constitution of the laws of the United States.
WHEREFORE respendent prays that said writ of habeas corpus be quashed and that said petition be dismissed and that he recover his costs.
div1.ab: Jno G Boyle
State of Washington, County of King,
ss:
div1.p: John G. Boyle being duly sworn deposes and says that he is the respondent above named; that he has read and knows the contents of the foregoing return and the same is true as he verily believes.
div1.ab: Jno G Boule
div1.p: Subscribed and sworn to before me this 9th day of September, 1901.
div1.ab: A. N. Moore

Notary Public for Washington, residing at North Yakima, Wn..
Deputy Clerk U.S. District Court, District of Washington.
ORDINANCE NO. 265.
An Ordinance in Relation to Licenses.
The City Council of the City of North Yakima do Ordain as Follows:
div1.p: Section 1. That it shall be unlawful for any person, firm, corporation or company to engage in, prosecute or carry on any business, trade, profession or occupation within the corporate limits of the City of North Yakima, for which a license is required without having procured a license theretofore as hereinafter provided.

Section 2. It shall be lawful for any person, firm, corporation or company to conduct, manage or superintend any show or exhibition within the limits of the City of North Yakima or within one mile of the corporate limits thereof for which a license is required without having obtained a license therefor as hereinafter provided.
Section 3. That the fees or rates of license for the business, trades, professions and occupations hereinafter named, be and the same are hereby established as hereinafter set forth.

Section 4. Any person who shall keep or use for hire, within the City of North Yakima, any dray, cart, truck, wagon, carriage, coach, express wagon, hack, cab, gurney, omnibus or other vehickle, shall pay a license fee of twelve dollars per year for each horse or other animal kept for or used in such business in connection with a vehickl to be drawn by one horse or other animal, and twenty dollars per years for each pair of horses or other animals kept for or used in such business in connection with a vehickle to be drawn by two horses or other animals, and in case any such person shall keep or use for hire any vehickle to be drawn by more than two horses or other animals, a further fee of five dollars shall be required for each horse or other animal in addition to two. Such person shall pay said fee for one year in advance and such person shall receive a license to do business as a licensed teamster for one year from the date of said license and such license shall state that he is entitled to use in said business the number of horses or other animals therein specified, stating the number of single animals and the number of

pairs for which the license fee has been paid. If any person shall obtain a license under this section and shall thereafter increase the number of horses or other animals used by him in said business he shall obtain a license for such additional horses or other animals in the same manner as the original license and at the same rate as hereinbefore required for each horse or other animal in addition to two, provided that this ordinance shall not apply to livery stables so far as concerns the ordinary business of such stables.
Section 5. All shows and exhibitions hereafter conducted within the City of North Yakima or within one mile of the corporate limits thereof shall be licensed at the following rates:
For each circus and menagerie and sideshows exhibiting on the same ground, $100.00.
For any other show or exhibition, Five Dollars, provided that nothing herein contained shall apply to church fairs or other charitable entertainments.

Section 6. Auctioneers shall pay a license of Twenty Dollars per year, provided that a license may issue for a shorter period at the rate of $2.00 per day and no license shall authorize any person other than the licensee named therein to carry on such busines, provided that a license may issue to a partnership authorizing one member of such firm to engage in the occupation aforesaid at any given time and no more.

Section 7. Each hawker or pedler of goods, wares and merchandise shall pay a license fee of $400.00 per quarter, provided that such license may be taken our for a term less than one quarter at the rate of $25.00 per day, and provided that no person shall be required to take out a license for peddling newspapers, books, magazines, fruit, bread, meat, milk, ice or other products of Yakima County.
Section 8. Every pawnbroker shall pay a license fee of twenty five dollars per quarter and license shall be issued for a shorter period than one quarter.

Section 9. Every person who posts or tacks up, bills or advertisements of circuses, menageries, shows, operas, concerts, theatres, exhibitions and other public amusements, tobacco, baking powder, patent medicine
and other commercial advertisements, shall pay a license fee of ten dollars per year.
Section 10. The license fee for each riding gallery, commonly called merry-go-round, shall be twenty-five dollars per day.
Section 11. The license fee for each knife-board, cane-rack, ring board or other like device shall be five dollars per day.
Section 12. The license fee for each of the following businesses, trades, professions and occupations shall be as follows:
For each doll-rack or other device for throwing balls or other projectiles for a prize, $1.00 per day.
For each grapho-phone, photograph or other electrical machine one dollar per day or five dollars per month.
For each striking machine, lifting machine or other device for testing strength one dollar per day.
For long tester or other like machine one dollar per day.
For each shooting gallery, ten dollars per month.

Section 13. Any person desiring a license to engage in or carry on any business, trades, profession or other occupation, hereinbefore mentioned, shall have a license granted him by presenting to the City Clerk the receipt of the City treasureer for the amount fixed by this ordinance as a license therefore, which receipt shall set forth the kind of business for which a license is desired and no license shall be issued by the City Clerk until such license fee has been paid to the City treasurer, and every license shall be granted for the period specified in this ordinance and shall have the seal of the city affixed thereto and specify the business, trade, profession or occupation for which the same is granted, the name and place of business of the person or persons taking out the same and the time for which such license is to run and the date of granting such license and no license shall be transferrable except on order of the City Council.

Section 14. Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be deemed guilty of the misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than ten nor more than one hundred dollars.
Section 15. All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with this ordinance are hereby repealed.
Passed the Council April 4th, 1898.
div1.ab: Attest: H. B. Doust, City Clerk.
Approved April 8, 1898. O.A. Fachter, Mayor.
Ex. "B."
ORDINANCE NO. 298.
div1.p: An Ordinance to amend Sections in 1 and 10 of Ordinance No. 265 entitled "An Ordinance relating to Licenses", approved April 5, 1898.
The City Council of the City of North Yakima do ordain as follows:

Section 1. That section 1 of Ordinance No. 265 entitled "An Ordinance relating to Licenses", approved April 5, 1898, is hereby amended to read as follows: Section 1. That it shall be unlawful for any person or the officers and employes of any firm, corporation or company, to engage in, prosecute or carry on any business, trade profession or occupation within the corporate limits of the City of North Yakima, for which a license is required without having firest procured a license therefor as hereafter provided and any person and the officers and employes of any firm, corporation or company who shall violate any of the provisions of this ordinance shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor, and upon convinction thereof shall be fined not less than Five Dollars nor more than Three Hundred Dollars for each offense.

Section 2. That section 10 of Ordinance No. 265, entitled "An Ordinance relating to Licenses", approved April 5th, 1898, be amended to read as follows: "Section 10. The License fee for which each riding gallery commonly called a Merry-go-round, shall be fifteen dollars per day, provided however that if a license for such riding gallery or merry-go-round is taken out for ten days or more, the license fee therefore shall ne ten dollars per day."
Section 3. This Ordinance shall be in force and effect from and after Five days after its passage and publication.
Passed the Council the 3rd day of September, 1900.
Approved the 4th day of September, 1900.
Attest: H. B. Doust, City Clerk.
div1.ab: (Seal)
div1.p: Geo. S. Hough, Mayor Pro tem.
In the Police Court of the City of North Yakima, Washington, County of Yakima, and State of Washington, Before W. I. LInce, Police Justic
div1.ab:
State of Washington, County of Yakima,
ss:
People of the State of Washington, vs. Fred S. Walton.
div1.p: Vestal Snyder, being first duly sworn, on oath says, that at the City of North Yakima, Yakima County, State of Washington, on the 5th day of September, 1901, said Fred S. Walton, did violate section seven of ordinance number 265, entitled an ordinance in relation to licenses" duly passed by the City Council of said City of North Yakima, on the 4th day of April, 1898, and approved by the Mayor of said City, numbered 298, duly passed by the City Council of said Mayor of said City, on the 4th day of September, 1900, and approved by the entitled an ordinance to amend 1 and 10 of ordinance number 265, entitled as follows; Then and there being the said Fred S. Walton did then and there hawk certain goods, wares and merchandise to-wit: "Quaker herbs", by selling the same at public out cry, in a public place within the City of North Yakima aforesaid, without first having otained a license so to do, in pursuance of the provisions of said ordinances. Said City of North Yakima, is a municipal corporation organized and existing under and by virtue of the laws of the State of Washington, and at all times herein mentioned was such municipal corporation.
Contrary to the forms of said ordinance of the City of North Yakima and the statute in such cases made and provided, and against the peace and dignity of the State of Washington.
div1.ab: Vestal Snyder.
div1.p: Subscribed and sworn to before me this 5th day of September, 1901
div1.ab: W. I. Lince, Police Justice of the City of Yakima, Washington.

State of Wash. vs. Fred S. Walton.
Justice Docket.

State of Washington, County of Yakima,
ss:

In Justice Peace Court before J. A. Taggard, Justice of the Peace.
Action for violating City Ord.
Officer, J. G. Boyle. Attys. Vestal Snyder, Plff. "H.J. Snively, Deft.
div1.p: Be it remembered that on this 6th day of September, A.D. 1901, the papers in this case complaint warrant aff. for change of venue from City Police Judge, W. I. Lince were filed in this Court, the complaint against defendant is for violating ordinances of the City of North Yakima, Nos. 265 and 298 and verified by Vestal Snyder. The defendant in Court and represented by H. J. Snively and City atty. Vestal Snyder. Defendant plead not guilty. All papers and facts on record admitted and after hearing argument of respective counsel, it is ordered and adjudged the defendant hereing Fred S. Walton, pay a fine of $5.00 and costs of this action, taxed at $1.70 and in default of payment of said fine and costs, viz. $6.70 he be confined in City Jail of the City of North Yakima, until paid or he be otherwise discharged by due process of law.
Dated Sept., 6, 1901
J. A. Taggard Justice of the Peace.
div1.ab: COMMITMENT UPON SENTENCE.
In Justice Court North Yakima Precinct.

State of Washington, County of Yakima,
ss:
div1.p: TO any city Marshal, Keeper of City Jail in City of North Yakima, Greeting:

WHEREAS, at a Justice Court held at my office in said County, for the trial of Fred S. Walton, for the offense hereinafter stated, the said Fred S. Walton was convicted of having on the 5th day of September, 1901, in said County, did violate ordinance Nos. 265 and 298 of City of North Yakima and upon conviction the Court did adjudge the and determine that the said Fred S. Walton pay a fine of Five Dollars and one and 70/100 dollars costs of suit and in default of payment of said fine and costs that he be imprisoned in the city jail, City of North Yakima, Yakima County, Washington, until such fine and costs are paid, at the rate of three dollars per day, not to exceed three days.

THEREFORE, You, the said Marshal are commanded in the name of the people of the State of Washington, forthwith to convey and deliver the said Fred S. Walton to the said Keeper, and you, the said Keeper, are hereby commanded to receive the said Fred S. Walton into your custody in said jail, and him there safely keep until said judgment is fully satisfied as above set forth, or until he shall thence be discharged by due course of law.
Dated this 4th day of September, 1901.
div1.ab: J. A. Taggard, Justice of the Peace.
